Government.title: Bond rebound uncertain as Trump plans overshadow Fed rate cuts
Government.content: Prospects of a near-term rebound in the $28-trillion U.S. government bond market are faltering, as Donald Trump's return to the White House is expected to usher in fiscally expansive policies

Government.title: Analysis-Big US Bond Managers Steer Clear of Long-Dated Government Debt
Government.content: NEW YORK (Reuters) - A number of U.S. bond managers at firms in charge of trillions of dollars of assets are steering clear of long-term U.S. government bonds as they expect fiscal worries to spur

Government.title: A global bond sell-off is deepening as investors pare Fed rate cut ...
Government.content: A combination of fewer rate cuts and an increasing term premium associated with widening government budget deficits are key drivers for this global selloff, said market watchers. A sell-off in global bond markets is accelerating, fueling concerns over government finances and raising the specter of higher borrowing costs for consumers and businesses around the world. Bond yields have mostly been rising globally with the U.S. 10-year Treasury yield touching a fresh 14-month high of 4.799% on Monday, as investors reassess the pace at which the Federal Reserve might lower interest rates. The U.S. economy is strengthening faster than foreseen, which means the Federal Reserve has less or no room to cut interest rates, and the bond market is reflecting that, said Ben Emons, founder of FedWatch Advisors.

Government.title: US debt reckoning escalates sharply as top bond buyer pulls back from ...
Government.content: Pimco said it's reducing exposure to long-term U.S. bonds amid concerns about soaring federal deficits and debt. Bond giant Pimco significantly ramped up a market backlash against soaring U.S. debt by announcing plans to reduce exposure to long-term Treasuries. In a note on Monday, the world’s biggest active bond fund manager referenced "bond vigilantes," a term coined by Wall Street veteran Ed Yardeni in the 1980s, describing traders who protest massive deficits by selling off bonds to push yields higher. Debt held by the public, or the amount the U.S. owes to outside lenders after borrowing on financial markets, is already at about 100% of GDP, with that ratio soon expected to blow past the all-time record set in the immediate aftermath of World War II.

 Over those two months, Macerich issued $534 million in new debt at an average interest rate of 6.5%, sold its share of One Westside for $175 million, and then used the proceeds to retire approximately $670 million of debt at the company’s share with a weighted average interest rate of about 5.5%.  While any new issuance is likely to be at a higher rate than the expiring interest rate, we believe management should not have any issue replacing the near-term debt maturities with new issuances as they come due.”
